Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Linking coexistence at local and regional scales by assessing a dormancy-dispersal tradeoff
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how and if species can coexist stably in a fragmented habitat where patches are connected by dispersal is key to understanding the maintenance of biodiversity. The coexistence of similar species?ones that feed at the same level in a food chain, have similar life histories, and share predators?requires some form of tradeoff such that each is either limited by different resources or enemies, or each is a superior competitor to the other at some points in either space, time, or both. This project will elucidate the differences in life-history strategies of two grazing zooplankton, Moina macrocopa and Daphnia pulex/pulicaria, in a freshwater rock-pools on an island off the coast of Maine, USA. The dormancy and dispersal of each species will be examined to determine if these differences promote coexistence either alone or in combination with spatial and temporal variation. This study will experimentally test whether one species is superior at remaining dormant while one species is superior at dispersing, and will model whether or not this allows these two species to coexist. This project will train one Ph.D. student and multiple undergraduate students through field-assistantships and mentored independent projects. The research will be communicated to the public, K-12 students, and undergraduates from many institutions at a nearby biological field station. The research itself promotes the progress of science and has implications for national welfare through application to the management of biodiversity of fragmented habitats; the project also supports education and diversity.

Understanding how and if species can coexist stably in a fragmented habitat is key to understanding the maintenance of biodiversity. The coexistence of similar species?ones that feed at the same trophic level, have similar life histories, and share predators?requires some form of tradeoff such that each is either limited by different resources or enemies, or each is a superior competitor to the other at some points in either space, time, or both. The differences in life-history strategies of two grazing zooplankton, Moina macrocopa and Daphnia pulex/pulicaria, will be elucidated for a freshwater rock-pool metacommunity on an island off the coast of Maine, USA. Life history strategies relating to dormancy and dispersal of each species will be examined and used to determine if these differences promote coexistence either alone or in combination with spatial and temporal variation. This study will experimentally test (1) whether one species is superior at remaining dormant while one species is superior at dispersing, and (2) whether or not this allows these two species to coexist in this metacommunity by measuring the necessary relationships to parameterize a mathematical dormancy-dispersal model to test the conditions for coexistence. The spatial and temporal dispersal rates of diapausing eggs and their establishment success will be measured by stocking focal pools surrounded by other pools in which the species are initially absent. These data will be combined with data on competition outcomes in both artificial mesocosms and manipulated rock pools. In addition to furthering our understanding of the maintenance of biodiversity, which can be applied to the management of naturally and anthropogenically fragmented habitats, this project will train one Ph.D. student and multiple undergraduate students through field-assistantships and mentored independent projects. Furthermore, the information about this project will be disseminated to visitors to Shoals Marine Laboratory, which includes the public, K-12 students, and undergraduates from many institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organisms face a variety of stressors and challenges throughout their life history, and adapting to deal with those stressors is key to producing a lineage that survives. Organisms have developed a remarkable array of survival strategies, but we know little about how similar species navigate stressors, both similar and different, in metapopulations. Metapopulations are groups subpopulations living in similar habitats connected by dispersal. Understanding the persistence of metapopulations is increasingly critical as anthropogenic habitat fragmentation creates more of them. Over the course of my dissertation I have tried to understand, in one ecological system, how dispersal, resources, and stressors all play into the distribution of organisms across a landscape, how this influences and is influenced by their life histories, and ultimately how this influences their long-term persistence.

I study these questions in a system of ca. 5000 rock pools distributed around the periphery of Appledore Island, that form habitat for metapopulations of freshwater invertebrates. Because the pools are small and embedded in rock, they are subject to dramatic temperature changes, they can dry out if there is too little rain, and they can be splashed by the ocean, subjecting the freshwater organisms within them to saltiness they may not be able to handle. Several of these species make up a tri-trophic food web: algae that are eaten by two species of cladoceran zooplankton that are in turn eaten by a predatory insect. My work has primarily focused on the cladoceran zooplankton herbivores Moina macrocopa and Daphnia pulex/pulicaria. Moina and Daphnia are particularly interesting species to study because they make dormant eggs that can endure harsh environments and can also be passively dispersed either among pools or through time.

My research has followed several main threads. First, I wanted to know whether Moina and Daphnia compete for the algal food they eat. I found that they are not. This is because there is a very abundant algal community, which likely results from the many gulls that nest on the island and whose feces washes into the pools. Therefore, these species are not interacting even though they inhabit the same pools.

Next, I wanted to know if Moina and Daphnia use their dormant eggs to disperse in the same way. The answer to this question helps us understand how each species deals with the high variability of rock pool habitat quality in time and space. To answer this question, I quantified dormant egg wind dispersal and also looked at egg traits. I found that Moina dormant eggs have properties that probably mean they are dispersed in time, while Daphnia dormant eggs have properties like floating and being protected from the sun that mean they are more likely to disperse in space as well as in time. Thus, Daphnia use their dormant eggs to escape from the conditions in a particular pool, while Moina may persist by staying in a single pool and waiting for favorable conditions to return.

Next, I further delved into the question of how these two species use their dormant eggs to survive harsh conditions, and how their life histories are similar and different. In particular, I was interested in determining whether either species can use a cue from its environment to determine when it is best to produce or hatch from dormant eggs, or whether they rely on “bet hedging”, where they produce a mixture of eggs that hatch immediately, in case conditions stay favorable, and dormant eggs, in case conditions deteriorate. I found that in all measurable cases a combination of bet hedging and environmental cues are likely important in all cases, except that Moina is cued to produce dormant eggs in when there algal density is low relative to other pools. I was unable to obtain a good measure of Daphnia hatching.

Finally, I have begun to examine the population genetics of Moina. Based on my other findings, I expect that there will be little gene flow over long distances.

In addition to producing interesting research, my dissertation has provided important learning and training opportunities for both myself and the undergraduates who have assisted me. In total, I have been able to train and mentor four exceptional female undergraduates in association with this grant. These students have learned both field and lab skills, including counting zooplankton, analyzing chlorophyll samples, entering data, and measuring pool characteristics. I have also been involved with numerous outreach opportunities, including Cornell’s Expanding Your Horizons Program, which give middle school girls the opportunity to participate in short science workshops for a day. I also led numerous tours for visitors at Shoals Marine Lab where I worked, teaching them about my research and giving them insight into what scientists do. Together, these outreach opportunities have been a great way to get a broader group of people associated with science.
